intro: Acaena × ovina subsp. monachaena, commonly known as the New Zealand bracken bush, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and compound leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense heads, followed by distinctive, spiny fruits. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in forest margins and wetlands. Its ecological role includes providing habitat and food for various native wildlife species.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena × ovina subsp. monachaena is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the central and southern regions. This subspecies thrives in dry, open habitats such as shrublands and grasslands. It is commonly associated with coastal and inland areas with well-drained soils. The plant is part of the bramble family and is known for its distinctive spiny fruits.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena × ovina subsp. monachaena was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the broader introduction of the Acaena genus for ornamental purposes. This subspecies has since become naturalized in certain regions of the country. It is commonly found in coastal and lowland areas, often growing in disturbed soils. However, it is not considered invasive and has a limited ecological impact.
